result.markdown:
--- title: "Chapter 8" author: "Robert W. Walker" date: "2022-10-01" categories: [R] --- 8.3.2 Data exercises For Exercises 1–4, use the speed_dating set used earlier in this chapter. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} speed_dating <- read.csv("http://peopleanalytics-regression-book.org/data/speed_dating.csv") employee_survey <- read.csv("http://peopleanalytics-regression-book.org/data/employee_survey.csv") ``` ::: The codebook for the data can be found [here](http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~gelman/arm/examples/speed.dating/Speed%20Dating%20Data%20Key.doc). 1. Split the data into two sets according to the `gender` of the participant. Run standard binomial logistic regression models on each set to determine the relationship between the `dec` decision outcome and the input variables `samerace, agediff, attr, intel and prob`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(skimr) library(kableExtra) names(speed_dating) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "iid" "gender" "match" "samerace" "race" "goal" [7] "dec" "attr" "intel" "prob" "agediff" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # 1 is male, 0 is female SDM <- speed_dating %>% filter(gender==1) SDF <- speed_dating %>% filter(gender==0) speed_dating %>% group_by(gender) %>% skim(dec, samerace, agediff, attr, intel, prob) %>% kable() %>% scroll_box() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
skim_type skim_variable gender n_missing complete_rate numeric.mean numeric.sd numeric.p0 numeric.p25 numeric.p50 numeric.p75 numeric.p100 numeric.hist
numeric dec 0 0 1.0000000 0.3654398 0.4816108 0 0 0 1 1 ▇▁▁▁▅
numeric dec 1 0 1.0000000 0.4742489 0.4993960 0 0 0 1 1 ▇▁▁▁▇
numeric samerace 0 0 1.0000000 0.3962715 0.4891805 0 0 0 1 1 ▇▁▁▁▅
numeric samerace 1 0 1.0000000 0.3953267 0.4889790 0 0 0 1 1 ▇▁▁▁▅
numeric agediff 0 94 0.9775335 3.6584352 3.0612015 0 1 3 5 32 ▇▁▁▁▁
numeric agediff 1 104 0.9752027 3.6584352 3.0612015 0 1 3 5 32 ▇▁▁▁▁
numeric attr 0 101 0.9758604 5.9192995 2.0017544 0 5 6 7 10 ▂▃▇▇▂
numeric attr 1 101 0.9759180 6.4600293 1.8586750 0 5 7 8 10 ▁▂▇▇▃
numeric intel 0 147 0.9648662 7.4473619 1.6098729 0 7 8 8 10 ▁▁▃▇▃
numeric intel 1 149 0.9644731 7.2899876 1.4848264 0 6 7 8 10 ▁▁▃▇▃
numeric prob 0 164 0.9608031 5.2156716 2.1431138 0 4 5 7 10 ▂▃▇▅▁
numeric prob 1 145 0.9654268 5.1994320 2.1162607 0 4 5 7 10 ▂▅▇▅▁
````` ::: ::: ### Model Estimates for the Two Groups ```{.r .cell-code} Model.F <- glm(dec~samerace+agediff+attr+intel+prob, data=SDF, family=binomial(link="logit")) Model.M <- glm(dec~samerace+agediff+attr+intel+prob, data=SDM, family=binomial(link="logit")) library(stargazer) stargazer(Model.F, Model.M, type = "html", column.labels = c("Female","Male")) ```
Dependent variable:
dec
FemaleMale
(1)(2)
samerace-0.053-0.137*
(0.078)(0.080)
agediff-0.002-0.019
(0.012)(0.013)
attr0.547***0.778***
(0.025)(0.031)
intel0.091***-0.079**
(0.029)(0.031)
prob0.228***0.325***
(0.020)(0.021)
Constant-5.788***-6.113***
(0.259)(0.272)
Observations3,8903,899
Log Likelihood-2,045.016-1,954.047
Akaike Inf. Crit.4,102.0333,920.095
Note:*p<0.1; **p<0.05; ***p<0.01
- `samerace` has no clear relationship to the decision for females but leads to less likelihood for wishing to see the person again for males. - `agediff` is not clearly related to the decision for either males or females. - `attr` *attraction* is positively related to the decision though the effect is stronger for males than females. *I will say more about this below.* - `intel` *intelligence* is positively related to `yes` for females but negatively related to `yes` for males. - `prob` *the probability that the other person will say yes on a 1 to 10 scale* is positively related to `yes` for both males and females. Personally, it makes more sense to me to estimate this as a common but stratified model because it allows me to identify where things differ. There are two ways to assess that. I will use `anova` and a formal model $\chi^2$ but we could also just use the p-values for the interaction terms. Let's have a look at the result for the combined model and then confirm it with individual `anova` results. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Model.All <- glm(dec~gender*samerace+gender*agediff+gender*attr+gender*intel+gender*prob, data=speed_dating, family=binomial(link="logit")) summary(Model.All) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: glm(formula = dec ~ gender * samerace + gender * agediff + gender * attr + gender * intel + gender * prob, family = binomial(link = "logit"), data = speed_dating) Deviance Residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -3.0544 -0.8357 -0.3466 0.8712 2.9297 Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) (Intercept) -5.78827 0.25864 -22.380 < 2e-16 *** gender -0.32426 0.37564 -0.863 0.38801 samerace -0.05279 0.07835 -0.674 0.50047 agediff -0.00166 0.01248 -0.133 0.89418 attr 0.54728 0.02525 21.671 < 2e-16 *** intel 0.09061 0.02915 3.109 0.00188 ** prob 0.22789 0.02011 11.332 < 2e-16 *** gender:samerace -0.08444 0.11221 -0.753 0.45175 gender:agediff -0.01701 0.01816 -0.937 0.34898 gender:attr 0.23041 0.03963 5.814 0.00000000609 *** gender:intel -0.16932 0.04231 -4.002 0.00006292444 *** gender:prob 0.09668 0.02944 3.284 0.00102 ** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1) Null deviance: 10647.3 on 7788 degrees of freedom Residual deviance: 7998.1 on 7777 degrees of freedom (589 observations deleted due to missingness) AIC: 8022.1 Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 5 ``` ::: ::: This evidence suggests that attraction, intelligence, and the probability of a yes from the partner all differ in their effects on males and females. Partners of the same race and the age difference do not differ among males and females. To confirm this, let's look at the the `anova` results. They tell us the same thing though the p-values differ slightly. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} MA1 <- glm(dec~samerace+gender*agediff+gender*attr+gender*intel+gender*prob, data=speed_dating, family=binomial(link="logit")) anova(MA1, Model.All, test="Chisq") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Analysis of Deviance Table Model 1: dec ~ samerace + gender * agediff + gender * attr + gender * intel + gender * prob Model 2: dec ~ gender * samerace + gender * agediff + gender * attr + gender * intel + gender * prob Resid. Df Resid. Dev Df Deviance Pr(>Chi) 1 7778 7998.7 2 7777 7998.1 1 0.56613 0.4518 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} MA2 <- glm(dec~gender*samerace+agediff+gender*attr+gender*intel+gender*prob, data=speed_dating, family=binomial(link="logit")) anova(MA2, Model.All, test="Chisq") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Analysis of Deviance Table Model 1: dec ~ gender * samerace + agediff + gender * attr + gender * intel + gender * prob Model 2: dec ~ gender * samerace + gender * agediff + gender * attr + gender * intel + gender * prob Resid. Df Resid. Dev Df Deviance Pr(>Chi) 1 7778 7999.0 2 7777 7998.1 1 0.87545 0.3495 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} MA3 <- glm(dec~gender*samerace+gender*agediff+attr+gender*intel+gender*prob, data=speed_dating, family=binomial(link="logit")) anova(MA3, Model.All, test="Chisq") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Analysis of Deviance Table Model 1: dec ~ gender * samerace + gender * agediff + attr + gender * intel + gender * prob Model 2: dec ~ gender * samerace + gender * agediff + gender * attr + gender * intel + gender * prob Resid. Df Resid. Dev Df Deviance Pr(>Chi) 1 7778 8032.5 2 7777 7998.1 1 34.332 0.000000004648 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} MA4 <- glm(dec~gender*samerace+gender*agediff+gender*attr+intel+gender*prob, data=speed_dating, family=binomial(link="logit")) anova(MA4, Model.All, test="Chisq") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Analysis of Deviance Table Model 1: dec ~ gender * samerace + gender * agediff + gender * attr + intel + gender * prob Model 2: dec ~ gender * samerace + gender * agediff + gender * attr + gender * intel + gender * prob Resid. Df Resid. Dev Df Deviance Pr(>Chi) 1 7778 8014.2 2 7777 7998.1 1 16.099 0.00006013 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} MA5 <- glm(dec~gender*samerace+gender*agediff+gender*attr+gender*intel+prob, data=speed_dating, family=binomial(link="logit")) anova(MA5, Model.All, test="Chisq") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Analysis of Deviance Table Model 1: dec ~ gender * samerace + gender * agediff + gender * attr + gender * intel + prob Model 2: dec ~ gender * samerace + gender * agediff + gender * attr + gender * intel + gender * prob Resid. Df Resid. Dev Df Deviance Pr(>Chi) 1 7778 8008.9 2 7777 7998.1 1 10.82 0.001004 ** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 ``` ::: ::: 2. Run similar mixed models on these sets with a random intercept for iid. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(lme4) Model.F.Mixed <- glmer(dec~samerace+agediff+attr+intel+prob + (1 | iid), data=SDF, family=binomial(link="logit")) Model.M.Mixed <- glmer(dec~samerace+agediff+attr+intel+prob + (1 | iid), data=SDM, family=binomial(link="logit")) summary(Model.F.Mixed) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Generalized linear mixed model fit by maximum likelihood (Laplace Approximation) [glmerMod] Family: binomial ( logit ) Formula: dec ~ samerace + agediff + attr + intel + prob + (1 | iid) Data: SDF AIC BIC logLik deviance df.resid 3209.8 3253.6 -1597.9 3195.8 3883 Scaled residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -22.0221 -0.3654 -0.0874 0.3501 21.7704 Random effects: Groups Name Variance Std.Dev. iid (Intercept) 5.806 2.41 Number of obs: 3890, groups: iid, 268 Fixed effects: Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) (Intercept) -13.40398 0.61283 -21.872 < 2e-16 *** samerace 0.54951 0.11991 4.583 4.59e-06 *** agediff -0.03507 0.01971 -1.779 0.0752 . attr 0.97520 0.04464 21.846 < 2e-16 *** intel 0.40788 0.05013 8.136 4.08e-16 *** prob 0.62907 0.04229 14.874 < 2e-16 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Correlation of Fixed Effects: (Intr) samerc agedff attr intel samerace -0.153 agediff -0.092 -0.049 attr -0.620 0.047 -0.020 intel -0.666 0.058 -0.008 0.074 prob -0.510 0.043 -0.016 0.264 -0.006 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} summary(Model.M.Mixed) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Generalized linear mixed model fit by maximum likelihood (Laplace Approximation) [glmerMod] Family: binomial ( logit ) Formula: dec ~ samerace + agediff + attr + intel + prob + (1 | iid) Data: SDM AIC BIC logLik deviance df.resid 3180.4 3224.3 -1583.2 3166.4 3892 Scaled residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -23.8209 -0.3503 -0.0220 0.3691 26.7441 Random effects: Groups Name Variance Std.Dev. iid (Intercept) 4.541 2.131 Number of obs: 3899, groups: iid, 273 Fixed effects: Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) (Intercept) -12.60865 0.58896 -21.408 < 2e-16 *** samerace -0.09398 0.11258 -0.835 0.4038 agediff -0.03503 0.02005 -1.748 0.0805 . attr 1.19470 0.05052 23.647 < 2e-16 *** intel 0.22500 0.04870 4.620 0.00000383 *** prob 0.61915 0.03960 15.637 < 2e-16 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Correlation of Fixed Effects: (Intr) samerc agedff attr intel samerace -0.059 agediff -0.107 -0.046 attr -0.673 -0.027 0.023 intel -0.608 0.052 -0.047 0.019 prob -0.495 -0.086 0.010 0.268 -0.012 ``` ::: ::: The saturated model. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Model.All.Mixed <- glmer(dec~gender*samerace+gender*agediff+gender*attr+gender*intel+gender*prob + (1 | iid), data=speed_dating, family=binomial(link="logit"), control= glmerControl(optimizer = "bobyqa"), nAGQ=20) summary(Model.All.Mixed) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Generalized linear mixed model fit by maximum likelihood (Adaptive Gauss-Hermite Quadrature, nAGQ = 20) [glmerMod] Family: binomial ( logit ) Formula: dec ~ gender * samerace + gender * agediff + gender * attr + gender * intel + gender * prob + (1 | iid) Data: speed_dating Control: glmerControl(optimizer = "bobyqa") AIC BIC logLik deviance df.resid 6379.7 6470.2 -3176.8 6353.7 7776 Scaled residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -25.3849 -0.3585 -0.0617 0.3601 28.1651 Random effects: Groups Name Variance Std.Dev. iid (Intercept) 5.237 2.288 Number of obs: 7789, groups: iid, 541 Fixed effects: Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) (Intercept) -13.132720 0.566641 -23.176 < 2e-16 *** gender 0.240669 0.742928 0.324 0.745978 samerace 0.533202 0.118149 4.513 6.39e-06 *** agediff -0.033792 0.019477 -1.735 0.082742 . attr 0.958233 0.042302 22.652 < 2e-16 *** intel 0.398145 0.048981 8.128 4.35e-16 *** prob 0.614830 0.040263 15.270 < 2e-16 *** gender:samerace -0.628438 0.164008 -3.832 0.000127 *** gender:agediff -0.002149 0.028100 -0.076 0.939031 gender:attr 0.255398 0.061909 4.125 3.70e-05 *** gender:intel -0.160369 0.068051 -2.357 0.018443 * gender:prob 0.017481 0.054014 0.324 0.746211 --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Correlation of Fixed Effects: (Intr) gender samerc agedff attr intel prob gndr:s gndr:g gender -0.661 samerace -0.126 0.068 agediff -0.116 0.102 -0.045 attr -0.579 0.360 0.018 -0.007 intel -0.662 0.461 0.043 -0.001 0.028 prob -0.464 0.279 0.016 -0.003 0.204 -0.050 gender:smrc 0.092 -0.081 -0.721 0.032 -0.014 -0.031 -0.012 gender:gdff 0.087 -0.143 0.029 -0.692 -0.001 -0.002 -0.003 -0.044 gender:attr 0.310 -0.564 0.012 -0.007 -0.613 0.018 -0.075 -0.024 0.027 gender:intl 0.432 -0.618 -0.019 -0.005 0.016 -0.701 0.069 0.039 -0.017 gender:prob 0.278 -0.400 0.007 -0.007 -0.097 0.067 -0.695 -0.049 0.018 gndr:t gndr:n gender samerace agediff attr intel prob gender:smrc gender:gdff gender:attr gender:intl -0.053 gender:prob 0.140 -0.102 ``` ::: ::: 3. What different conclusions can you make in comparing the mixed models with the standard models? *The model comparisons should not differ in ways that depend on using the saturated or the separate models. First, there is evidence of random effects by ID. Comparing the AIC values, the mixed effects models fit better in both cases. Second, in the mixed model, females seem to prefer `samerace` partners [the result is positive and different from zero]; males do not. Without mixed effects, `samerace` was negative for males but has no effect with mixed effects. `agediff` is marginally different from zero and negative for both groups. Attraction is positive for both groups though more important for males. Intelligence is positive for both groups though stronger for females. The probability the partner will say yes is positively related and similar for both groups. Let's show them side by side.* ```{.r .cell-code} stargazer(Model.M, Model.M.Mixed, Model.F, Model.F.Mixed, column.labels = c("Male", "Male:RE", "Female", "Female.RE"), type="html") ```
Dependent variable:

Bayesian Inf. Crit.3,224.3213,253.628
Note:*p<0.1; **p<0.05; ***p<0.01
4. Experiment with some random slope effects to see if they reveal anything new about the input variables. *I will examine attraction*. ### Female ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Model.F.Mixed <- glmer(dec~samerace+agediff+attr+intel+prob + (1 + attr | iid), data=SDF, family=binomial(link="logit")) summary(Model.F.Mixed) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Generalized linear mixed model fit by maximum likelihood (Laplace Approximation) [glmerMod] Family: binomial ( logit ) Formula: dec ~ samerace + agediff + attr + intel + prob + (1 + attr | iid) Data: SDF AIC BIC logLik deviance df.resid 3180.9 3237.3 -1581.5 3162.9 3881 Scaled residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -6.8317 -0.3363 -0.0679 0.3176 9.9176 Random effects: Groups Name Variance Std.Dev. Corr iid (Intercept) 19.4694 4.4124 attr 0.2036 0.4512 -0.84 Number of obs: 3890, groups: iid, 268 Fixed effects: Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) (Intercept) -14.91109 0.76990 -19.367 < 2e-16 *** samerace 0.53325 0.12521 4.259 2.06e-05 *** agediff -0.02976 0.02046 -1.455 0.146 attr 1.13721 0.06704 16.964 < 2e-16 *** intel 0.42566 0.05286 8.053 8.09e-16 *** prob 0.66138 0.04540 14.568 < 2e-16 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Correlation of Fixed Effects: (Intr) samerc agedff attr intel samerace -0.132 agediff -0.088 -0.044 attr -0.752 0.040 0.000 intel -0.597 0.060 -0.004 0.098 prob -0.510 0.049 -0.017 0.283 0.029 optimizer (Nelder_Mead) convergence code: 4 (failure to converge in 10000 evaluations) Model failed to converge with max|grad| = 0.0696188 (tol = 0.002, component 1) failure to converge in 10000 evaluations ``` ::: ::: As it stands, the model for Female does not converge. Notice the warning/convergence status. I will let the optimizer evaluate the function up to 100,000 times; this will usually be sufficient unless the model is poorly behaved. This was also required for the fully saturated set of interactions with gender though I used more evaluation points for numerical integration in that case because we only had one set of random effects. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Model.F.Mixed <- glmer(dec~samerace+agediff+attr+intel+prob + (1 + attr | iid), data=SDF, family=binomial(link="logit"), control=glmerControl(optimizer="bobyqa", optCtrl=list(maxfun=100000))) summary(Model.F.Mixed) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Generalized linear mixed model fit by maximum likelihood (Laplace Approximation) [glmerMod] Family: binomial ( logit ) Formula: dec ~ samerace + agediff + attr + intel + prob + (1 + attr | iid) Data: SDF Control: glmerControl(optimizer = "bobyqa", optCtrl = list(maxfun = 100000)) AIC BIC logLik deviance df.resid 3180.9 3237.3 -1581.5 3162.9 3881 Scaled residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -6.8240 -0.3363 -0.0680 0.3175 9.9117 Random effects: Groups Name Variance Std.Dev. Corr iid (Intercept) 19.458 4.4111 attr 0.204 0.4516 -0.84 Number of obs: 3890, groups: iid, 268 Fixed effects: Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) (Intercept) -14.90921 0.76961 -19.372 < 2e-16 *** samerace 0.53502 0.12523 4.272 1.94e-05 *** agediff -0.02988 0.02046 -1.460 0.144 attr 1.13743 0.06704 16.968 < 2e-16 *** intel 0.42532 0.05285 8.047 8.47e-16 *** prob 0.66114 0.04539 14.565 < 2e-16 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Correlation of Fixed Effects: (Intr) samerc agedff attr intel samerace -0.133 agediff -0.088 -0.044 attr -0.752 0.040 0.000 intel -0.597 0.060 -0.004 0.098 prob -0.510 0.049 -0.017 0.283 0.028 ``` ::: ::: ### Males The same will happen with the Male model. I will go ahead and increase the set of function evaluations to allow convergence. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Model.M.Mixed <- glmer(dec~samerace+agediff+attr+intel+prob + (1 + attr | iid), data=SDM, family=binomial(link="logit"), control=glmerControl(optimizer="bobyqa", optCtrl=list(maxfun=100000))) summary(Model.M.Mixed) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Generalized linear mixed model fit by maximum likelihood (Laplace Approximation) [glmerMod] Family: binomial ( logit ) Formula: dec ~ samerace + agediff + attr + intel + prob + (1 + attr | iid) Data: SDM Control: glmerControl(optimizer = "bobyqa", optCtrl = list(maxfun = 100000)) AIC BIC logLik deviance df.resid 3141.0 3197.4 -1561.5 3123.0 3890 Scaled residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -7.1362 -0.3164 -0.0157 0.3299 8.2443 Random effects: Groups Name Variance Std.Dev. Corr iid (Intercept) 21.597 4.6473 attr 0.401 0.6333 -0.88 Number of obs: 3899, groups: iid, 273 Fixed effects: Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) (Intercept) -14.24697 0.76058 -18.732 < 2e-16 *** samerace -0.08803 0.11854 -0.743 0.4577 agediff -0.03799 0.02094 -1.814 0.0697 . attr 1.39953 0.08007 17.478 < 2e-16 *** intel 0.24653 0.05193 4.747 0.00000206 *** prob 0.65876 0.04302 15.313 < 2e-16 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Correlation of Fixed Effects: (Intr) samerc agedff attr intel samerace -0.051 agediff -0.075 -0.045 attr -0.790 -0.012 0.005 intel -0.536 0.051 -0.048 0.056 prob -0.477 -0.088 0.001 0.261 0.008 ``` ::: ::: For exercises 5–10, load the employee_survey data set via the `peopleanalyticsdata` package or download it from the internet. This data set contains the results of an engagement survey of employees of a technology company. Each row represents the responses of an individual to the survey and each column represents a specific survey question, with responses on a Likert scale of 1 to 4, with 1 indicating strongly negative sentiment and 4 indicating strongly positive sentiment. Subject matter experts have grouped the items into hypothesized latent factors as follows: Happiness is an overall measure of the employees current sentiment about their job. - Items beginning with `Ben` relate to employment benefits. - Items beginning with `Work` relate to the general work environment. - Items beginning with `Man` relate to perceptions of management. - Items beginning with `Car` relate to perceptions of career prospects. 5. Write out the proposed measurement model, defining the latent factors in terms of the measured items. $$(Ben1, Ben2, Ben3) = \alpha + \beta_{k}\textrm{Benefits} + \epsilon$$ $$(Man1, Man2, Man3) = \alpha + \beta_{k}\textrm{Managers} + \epsilon$$ $$(Work1, Work2, Work3) = \alpha + \beta_{k}\textrm{Workplace} + \epsilon$$ $$(Car1, Car2, Car3, Car4) = \alpha + \beta_{k}\textrm{Career} + \epsilon$$ 6. Run a confirmatory factor analysis on the proposed measurement model. Examine the fit and the factor loadings. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} meas_mod <- " Benefits =~ Ben1 + Ben2 + Ben3 Career =~ Car1 + Car2 + Car3 + Car4 Manager =~ Man1 + Man2 + Man3 Workplace =~ Work1 + Work2 + Work3 " library(lavaan) cfa_meas_mod <- lavaan::cfa(model = meas_mod, data = employee_survey, ordered = TRUE) lavaan::summary(cfa_meas_mod, fit.measures = TRUE, standardized = TRUE) Once satisfied with the fit of the measurement model, run a full structural equation model on the data. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} struc_mod <- " Benefits =~ Ben1 + Ben2 Career =~ Car1 + Car2 + Car3 + Car4 Manager =~ Man1 + Man2 + Man3 Workplace =~ Work1 + Work2 + Work3 Happiness ~ Benefits + Career + Manager + Workplace " library(lavaan) library(performance) sem_model <- lavaan::sem(model = struc_mod, data = employee_survey, ordered=TRUE) lavaan::summary(sem_model, fit.measures = TRUE, standardized = TRUE, rsquare=TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` lavaan 0.6-12 ended Interpret the results of the structural model. Which factors appear most related to overall employee sentiment? Approximately what proportion of the variance in overall sentiment does the model explain? One can get an approximate $R^2$ value from the summary; in this case, it is approximately 0.56. 10. If you dropped measured items from your measurement model, experiment with assigning them to other factors to see if this improves the fit of the model. What statistics would you use to compare different measurement models?
